docs.lead_paragraph: Inside the Family Assistance Center on Pier 94, where bereaved relatives and surviving workers of the World Trade Center disaster are being urged to seek help of all kinds, it is as though the welfare state stumbled into paradise. The blue carpeting is thick enough to soothe the weariest step. No matter what language is spoken, there are interpreters to translate and explain. The banks of telephones are free, like the child care, the all-day buffet, and the kindness of strangers.

headline.main: On Pier 94, a Welfare State That Works, and a Possible Model for the Future
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FAMILY CENTER

docs.abstract: New York City, New York State and federal agencies are working together to aid bereaved relatives and surviving workers of World Trade Center disaster at Family Assistance Center on Manhattan pier; are eager to cut through rules and red tape to speed financial help to those in need; experts speculate on whether generosity to attack victims will change way government handles needy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students learn about the controversial 'harm reduction' approach to drug use and debate the various sides to this approach.

byline.original: By RACHEL MCCLAIN and ANDREA PERELMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Home visits from nurses who provide training in special exercises can help women suffering from bladder problems and incontinence after childbirth, researchers are reporting. Almost a third of women who give birth suffer from incontinence afterward. In an article published last week in The British Medical Journal, researchers from New Zealand said they had focused on women who were still having problems three months after childbirth.
docs.abstract: New Zealand researchers find home visits from nurses who provide training in special exercises can help women suffering from bladder problems and incontinence after childbirth (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: My $300 tax refund check arrived the day after Corbett's article appeared, and I can't think of a more worthy cause than Rebecca Gomperts and her Women on Waves Foundation. She is acting on her beliefs to work both locally and globally on the issue of preventing unwanted pregnancy. Jason Swartz San Francisco
docs.abstract: Jason Swartz letter on Sara Corbett's August 26 article praises Rebecca Gomperts and Women on Waves Foundation for working actively on issue of preventing unwanted pregnancy
